poem:
**Ink Withdrawn**

In the graying light 
where voices once 
called out—

now, silence.

New York's breath 
holds its ink,
like a lapsed wave, 

retreating from 
the print of shores, 

no longer endorsing
any name 
but its own.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "New York Times will no longer endorse candidates outside presidential races The New York Times will no longer endorse political candidates outside presidential elections, the newspaper announced on Monday. US newspapers have a long history of endorsing candidates, but the New York Times is joining some other publishers in moving away from the tradition – including the Miami Herald and Alden Global Capital, which owns titles such as the Chicago Tribune, the New York Daily". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
